course_outline:
Traditionally legal systems have been conceived as creatures of the nation-state. At the domestic level the state is given exclusive sovereignty to create, enforce and adjudicate laws that apply within its physical borders. In terms of the international legal order, states are both the creators of public international law through treaties and traditionally were the sole subjects of that body of law.

A variety of social, economic, technological and political trends which are generally associated with the notion of "globalization" have in recent years fundamentally altered the state-centred paradigm of the law. The increased flow of goods, capital, communications and people across borders has contributed to new challenges which individual states have difficulty regulating on their own. This has created an impetus towards regulating many issues at the international rather than　the national level. Additionally, the benefits of collective action in some areas provide states with a positive incentive to regulate such issues in an international forum rather than domestically.

In this course we will explore the above noted trends in a selected group of fields which demonstrate the ways in which international law and domestic law interact to address these problems. These range from major global issues which require collective action at the international level to avert potentially catastrophic outcomes - like climate change - to more niche areas in which interesting legal issues are being debated like the cross border protection of cultural property.

course_outline:
The purpose of the course is to provide an introduction to the contemporary Japanese legal system. This is done by examining a number of areas, namely Article 9 of the Constitution, Criminal Law and Procedure, Nationality, and Family Law. Within each area, some of the most relevant rules and institutions are selected, and they are studied not only in and by themselves, but taking into account their social, economic, and political foundations, as well as by comparing them to similar rules and institutions in other countries.

The course is designed with non-law students in mind, and is therefore accessible to those with no or little previous university-level experience in this field. An effort is made to highlight issues that are relevant for a wide future range of careers, including, but not limited to, business, public service, diplomacy, and national security.

Students are expected to read course materials in advance of the relevant lecture, and to engage in active discussion in the seminars. In addition, they have to complete a written assignment and prepare and deliver an oral presentation. All of these, together with a final exam, will contribute to students' final grades. Students will be provided with a list of possible topics for their research essays and can suggest others, subject to approval. The final exam will consist of two sections, one with multiple-choice questions and another one with essay-type questions.

Lectures and seminars will mainly take place on Wednesdays (fourth period), but some will be held on Wednesdays (first period).

The materials for this course will be provided in electronic format. Students are expected to follow current events in Japan by regularly reading a quality newspaper. They also check their e-mail regularly since the course convenor may send them additional materials.

By the end of the course students will have gained a basic understanding of some key areas of the Japanese legal system, and understood their social, economic, and political foundations. They will have compared them with similar ones in other countries. In addition, they will have gained some exposure to legal thought and techniques, and deepened their understanding of contemporary Japan. This will improve their capability of engaging with the country at all levels, from business and personal to diplomacy. Among other, non-specific skills, students will have had the chance to improve their reading comprehension, public speaking, research capability, and written expression.

course_outline:
The purpose of the course is to give students the chance to acquaint themselves with some key legal international documents, both public and private. Reading and discussing them should provide students with the opportunity to explore some of the legal foundations of international relations, and of the international financial markets. Students are expected to be active participants in class, since the course is based on active learning, reading, and comprehension, rather than the mere passive study of texts.

The course runs in parallel with Contemporary Japanese Law I, and students taking both should be able to combine the knowledge and skills gained. However, they are designed as independent courses and neither requires students to be following the other.

The first part of the course deals with private law documents. We shall begin with an examination of contracts, including the concept of a contract and an outline of its elements in the English Common Law. This will take us first to the contracts used to charter ships, followed by insurance. Next we will deal with legal documentation in the international financial markets, with a closer look at some derivatives. After some time for review, a mid-term exam will be held on all these topics.

We will then turn our attention to public international law, and some of the kinds of documents often encountered in that arena. We will begin with treaties, and an overview of their nature and place in the sources of International Law. This will be followed by a closer look at UNCLOS and the concept of the Exclusive Economic Zone. We shall next examine the Philippines' arbitration case against China at a seminar, both to learn more about UNCLOS and as an introduction to arbitration.

The course is designed with non-law students in mind, and is therefore accessible to those with no or little previous university-level experience in this field. An effort is made to highlight issues that are relevant for a wide future range of careers, including, but not limited to, business, public service, diplomacy, and national security.

Students are expected to read course materials in advance of the relevant lecture, and to engage in active discussion in class and the seminar. In addition, they have to complete a written assignment and prepare and deliver and oral presentation. All of these, together with a mid-term exam, participation in class, and a final exam, will contribute to students' final grades. Students will be sent some possible presentation topics but are encouraged to suggest one themselves, subject to approval by their course convenor. The mid-term exam will be multiple-choice, while the final exam will consist of a mixture of multiple-choice questions and essay-type questions.

Lectures and seminars will take place on Thursdays (3rd period), but also sometimes on Wednesdays (1st period).

The materials for this course will be provided in electronic format. Students are expected to follow current events in Japan and worldwide by regularly reading a quality newspaper. In particular, they should make an effort to follow any developments related to the topics included in the syllabus. They should also check their e-mail regularly, since the course convenor may send notices concerning the development of the course, or share relevant news or materials with students.

By the end of the course students will have been exposed to a range of legal materials, from both the private and public spheres. This will have contributed to their understanding of the law and the context in which it operates. It will also provide a foundation for the use of legal documentation in their future careers, be they in the private sector or in public service. Concerning the non-specific skills that students will reinforce, they include reading comprehension, summing up of texts both orally and in writing, public speaking, and written expression.

Law is an amalgam of pragmatism, doctrine, and overriding theory. Registration systems are one of the most common supporting devices for the pragmatic implementation of legal rules, in fields ranging from immigration to corporate law. With the advent of the Internet, direct interaction with government-operated and government-recognized registration systems (both read and write) has become a more common experience.

In Seminar IA/IIA, students will each serve as rapporteur on a specific registration system of their choice. Reports will progress in parallel through the term, examining a common set of questions about each registration "gateway", spanning data collection, data storage and management, public accessibility and accountability, laws dependent upon collected data, and related public discourse.

Rapporteurs will each prepare two summary reports on progress during the course.

Given the topic, rapporteurs are certain to encounter freedom of information and privacy issues in the course of investigation. A final examination will pose general questions on these topics.

course_outline:
'Critical approaches' is used as an umbrella term and refers to a bundle of loosely related approaches adopted by a growing number of scholars who engage critically with the paradoxes hidden in international law. The aim of 'critique' is to identify underlying fundamental shortcomings of international law and to assess the rational potential of the international legal order. Opinions about the current role and significance of Critical International Law (CIL) vary within the discipline of international legal theory. As a matter of fact, vast literature has been written in the name for example of "New Approaches of International Law" or "Third World Approaches to International Law".

This course introduces to a range of writings by scholars from around the world, from a wide field of legal interests and backgrounds, and with different critical perspectives. As an invitation to debate and to engage in a process of critical evaluation, it reflects on that project and questions further both its impact on contemporary international legal scholarship and its potential for practicing international lawyers.

But behind the modern Japanese history, there has always been inner tension between traditional values and Western ones. Such tension is most clearly represented in the effort of Japanese thinkers to accept critically or sometimes refuse fiercely "advanced" thoughts from western world.

In this Course, we read the textbook which introduces Japanese intellectual history since Meiji Era, and try to understand this tension thorough it. In the globalizing world we live in, it is also meaningful to touch sincere footsteps of Japanese thinkers endeavoring to bridge the gap between their own thoughts and morals and the western ones. From the macro view point we focus the shift from an era in which the "state" sought to seize and control over their economies to an era in which the ideas of competetion, openness, privatization and deregulation have captured world economic thinking.

course_objective: The aim of the seminar is to provide students with effective preparation on how to take part in an international moot competition. First, a general overview of what an international moot competition is will be provided. Then, the seminar aims to provide students with the basic skills for preparing a dispute before an arbitration tribunal: analysis of the problem; research on the relevant legal issues; drafting a memorandum in arbitration (both form claimant and respondent sides), presenting the case orally. All those activities will be initially carried out under the supervision of the instructors in order to ensure that students are properly prepared. Then, as the seminar proceeds, a greater degree of autonomy and initiative will be expected. Students will be encouraged to develop their own critical views and defensive strategies on the Moot case. New, truly international, learning experiences are flourishing, and in particular extremely useful and challenging international commercial arbitration moots. One of the most prestigious is the Vis (East) Moot. As the organizers of this competition state, the Vis Moot was created as a clinical tool for training law students in crucial aspects of the procedure: research, drafting and advocacy. The goals of the Moot are the promotion and study of international commercial arbitration and the training of tomorrow's legal leaders in methods of alternate dispute resolution.

First we examine how Japanese family law has developed by comparing it with the other East Asian countries such as China and Korea. We will then consider some currently debated issues in Japanese family law, including the existence of discrimination between legitimate child and illegitimate child in determining the division of property in succession, and issues related to artificial reproductive technology (ART). We will find out how the traditional concept of a parent-child relationship remains and appears even as society itself seems like to have been radically changed through the influences of Western culture.

Secondly, students will do a further survey of the wider Asian perspective with samples from South Asian and South East Asian countries where the application of religious and customary laws remains important, creating conflicts with general laws. The conflicts of such legal systems come from the adoption or transplantation of the legal systems of the suzerain states. We will examine how ex-colonies have maintained their own legal systems and their current situations, before discussing the best future.

course_outline:
This course offers an introduction to the broad world of "Anglo-American" law from a comparative perspective. Though the term "Anglo-American" suggests the topic relates solely to the laws of the United Kingdom and United States, it is generally used to describe the laws of countries using the common law system, including Canada, Singapore, India, Australia, New Zealand and a number of others. These countries together make up one of the two major legal traditions in the world, the other being the continental civil law system used in Europe and much of the rest of the world, including Japan.

The course intends to provide students with an understanding of the historical origins of the common law system, how it develops rules and responds to changing social, economic and other demands placed on it, and how lawyers and judges in common law systems use the law to approach disputes. As a comparative class, the different approaches used among different common law countries and in countries in the civil law world will be highlighted.

The course primarily will focus on private law - laws which govern private relations between individuals. This will explore rules in the field of employment law, property law, corporate law, trusts and torts. Laws in the realm of public law - laws which govern relations between private individuals and the state (such as criminal law) will also be touched on briefly.

course_objective: This lecture discusses the development of Japanese diplomacy since the end of the Second World War, and aims to deepen students' understanding of the characteristics of post-war Japanese diplomacy and how successive governments have perceived Japan's national interests as a whole. The first Diplomatic Bluebook issued by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Japan (MOFA) in 1957 specified three principles underpinning Japanese foreign policy: close cooperation with Western countries, international cooperation through United Nations activities and adherence to Japan's position as an Asian country. In the lecture students will examine whether these principles in postwar Japanese diplomacy have been subject to either changes in priority or friction.
course_outline:
The lecture first traces the historical evolution of Japanese diplomacy during the Cold War and post-Cold War periods. It then proceeds to look at various characteristics of Japanese diplomacy and the rationale on which it is premised. Finally, it evaluates Japanese diplomacy in the context of the current international political environment.

Postwar Japanese Diplomacy

Immediately after the Second World War, Japan's defeat against the allied forces prevented it from adopting an explicit foreign policy. Occupation authorities were tasked with demilitarizing and democratizing Japanese society, and this led to the Constitution of 1946, which became the centerpiece of the democratization of Japan. However, after the beginning of the Cold war in Asia, Japan took on a different role in the US's Asian strategy. In 1951 Treaty of Peace with Japan and the Japan-US Security Treaty were both signed on the same date in San Francisco.

The Yoshida Doctrine and Japanese Diplomacy

It is safe to say that the Yoshida Doctrine eventually emerged as the most important pillar of postwar Japanese diplomacy. It placed absolute priority on economic recovery and development, while simultaneously maintaining a low-key diplomatic profile and leaving Japan's national defense largely in the hands of the United States. Successive governments of postwar Japan were forced to accept the international environment as a fait accompli and hope the American security system would hold up.

Japanese Diplomacy toward Asian countries

On the other hand, Japan's diplomacy toward Asian countries at the time was largely based on an economic policy in the form of its ODA programs, rather than a genuine foreign policy. Especially for East Asian neighbors, the Japan-US Security Treaty posed a threat to regional stability and cooperation in Asia. Despite these conditions, the Fukuda Doctrine of 1977 pledged that Japan would never again become a military power and that Japan would build up relationship of mutual trust with Southeast Asian countries, via the so-called "hear- to-heart" diplomacy.

The end of the Cold War and Japanese Diplomacy

The end of the Cold War called into question the purpose of the security alliance with the United States. However, while policymakers advocated a transformation of the alliance, Japanese diplomacy in fact increasingly emphasized the importance of the bilateral relationship with the United States. The Koizumi cabinet, for example, actively supported American military operations in Iraq and Afghanistan, and dispatched SDF troops to both conflict zones in a surprising departure from Japan's longstanding policy of not deploying military forces overseas.

In the lecture, students will gain a clear perspective on Japanese diplomacy in the 21th century and be able to evaluate how Japanese diplomacy has genuinely contributed to stability and prosperity in Asia, and in East Asia in particular.

course_outline: This is an introductory course on international relations of East Asia taught in an intensive manner over a period of four days. East Asia has become the most important region of the world with its economic rise and strategic importance, and presents a plethora of important interesting security and economic issues. In this course we will (1) introduce essential IR theories that will help us analyse these issues; (2) discuss several key issues including, but not limited to, the rise of China, North Korean nuclear weapons issue, the "history problem" controversy, financial cooperation and FTAs; and (3) engage with classmates in discussions and presentations. Hence your task is to think critically about the issues covered in the course and evaluate which theoretical approach(es) best explain major trends in the level of cooperation and conflict in the region. The course does not assume that you have any background in international relations theory or in East Asian history.

course_outline:
Outline of Lecture Course:

Deliberative democracy is a growing branch of democratic theory that is very influential in contemporary political practice. In this course we will examine the theoretical origins of deliberative democracy, its difference from other streams of democratic theory, and its practice in various contexts ranging from the so-called 'mini-publics' and democratic innovations to its articulation at a systems level. We will do so in three interrelated modules.

The first module will focus on the deliberative turn in democratic theory, and examine the theoretical foundations of this approach particularly as advanced by Jürgen Habermas. The second module will look at the practice of deliberative democracy at a micro level and discuss various examples of participatory practices and 'mini-publics' from around the world. Finally, the third module will cover the issues related to the 'systemic turn' in deliberative democracy, discuss the manifestation of this turn in practice, and the ways of studying this turn empirically.

Course Requirements

All students are expected to attend lass regularly, read assigned materials and participate in class discussion. Students are also expected to present and write a final research paper (essay) on a subject that they have chosen and worked through during this course.

•Attendance and participation in class discussions (20%):

All students are expected to attend class regularly, read assigned materials and participate in class discussions.

•Research paper/essay (50%):

Students are also expected to present and write a final research paper on a subject that they have chosen and worked on during this course. The research paper should be maximum 4000 words on a subject that students have chosen in the context. The research paper should take a position in a particular debate and formulate a clear argument on the issue at stake.

•Presentation of research paper in class (30%):

Students are required to present their research paper in class prior to its final submission. We will determine the format of the paper presentation in class depending on the number of students undertaking this course.

Class content

1.Module 1: The deliberative turn in democratic theory

2.The Habermasian idea of deliberative democracy

3.Deliberative democracy beyond Habermas: Friendly and not so friendly criticisms

4.Module 2: Mini-publics and deliberative democracy

5.Internal dynamics of deliberation: Speech styles and reasoning in public deliberation

6.Examples of mini-publics in practice

7.Key issues in public deliberation: Legitimation, representation, polarization

8.Module 3: The systemic turn in deliberative democracy

9.Deliberation and social movements

10.Methods of studying deliberative systems

course_title: Special Problems (Introduction to International Commercial Arbitration)
course_objective: The aim of the seminar is to provide students with effective knowledge of international commercial arbitration. First, a general overview of the subject will be presented, in order to allow everybody to have a common frame of reference. Then, each single phase of the procedure will be analyzed in detail, from the arbitration agreement to the recognition and enforcement of the award. To better understand the interaction between theoretical and normative framework and practical problems, students will have to read and comment also on materials taken from actual cases. After the end of the seminar, students should have acquired a good knowledge of, inter alia, the UNICTRAL Model Law, the New York Convention and the main problems and issues which are currently debated among arbitration scholars and practitioners.
textbooks: due to the peculiar nature of the seminar, there is no need of a general textbook for students. Lessons will be based on specifically created Power Point presentations. Also, copies of some relevant readings will be distributed to students on a regular basis, via the online syllabus system. However, as a support textbook, students may want to use N. Blackaby, C. Partasides (with Alan Redfern and Martin Hunter), Redfern and Hunter on International Arbitration - Student version, Oxford, Oxford University Press, 5th edition, 2009.
course_outline: International commercial arbitration is becoming more and more important in the field of cross-border disputed resolution. While most advanced nations already are already familiar with arbitration, there is a growing demand of expertise in this field from recent developing countries. The regulatory framework in the world is moving towards a "globalized" arbitration: there is widespread acceptance of international models as base for legislation (e.g. the UNCITRAL Model Law on International Commercial Arbitration) and the circulation of awards is made smoother by effective international instruments (e.g. the 1958 New York Convention of the recognition and enforcement of foreign arbitral awards), However, many countries are lagging back in term of effective appliance of those international tools: national resistances (both legislative, judicial and political) and the lack of arbitration theoretical and practical expertise among legislators, judges and professional operators is jeopardizing an effective and homogeneous success of arbitration all over the world. One tool to subvert this situation is trying to provide law students with a strong basis of notions in this field. This seminar focuses on both theoretical and practical issues in arbitration, covering a wide spectrum of subjects in order to provide a comprehensive picture of what international arbitration is.
prerequisites: Good command of English language (reading, speaking, and writing) is required. A basic knowledge of private international law and civil procedure is recommended.

Then, each single phase of the procedure will be analyzed in detail, from the arbitration agreement to the recognition and enforcement of the award. To better understand the interaction between theoretical and normative framework and practical problems, students will have to read and comment also on materials taken from actual cases. course_outline:
Introduction to International Commercial Arbitration

International commercial arbitration is becoming more and more important in the field of cross-border disputed resolution. While most advanced nations already are already familiar with arbitration, there is a growing demand of expertise in this field from recent developing countries. The regulatory framework in the world is moving towards a "globalized" arbitration: there is widespread acceptance of international models as base for legislation (e.g. the UNCITRAL Model Law on International Commercial Arbitration) and the circulation of awards is made smoother by effective international instruments (e.g. the 1958 New York Convention of the recognition and enforcement of foreign arbitral awards), However, many countries are lagging back in term of effective appliance of those international tools: national resistances (both legislative, judicial and political) and the lack of arbitration theoretical and practical expertise among legislators, judges and professional operators is jeopardizing an effective and homogeneous success of arbitration all over the world. One tool to subvert this situation is trying to provide law students with a strong basis of notions in this field. This seminar focuses on both theoretical and practical issues in arbitration, covering a wide spectrum of subjects in order to provide a comprehensive picture of what international arbitration is.

First, a general overview of what an international moot competition is will be provided. Then, the seminar aims to provide students with the basic skills for preparing a dispute before an arbitration tribunal: analysis of the problem; research on the relevant legal issues; drafting a memorandum in arbitration (both form claimant and respondent sides), presenting the case orally. All those activities will be initially carried out under the supervision of the instructors in order to ensure that students are properly prepared. Then, as the seminar proceeds, a greater degree of autonomy and initiative will be expected. Students will be encouraged to develop their own critical views and defensive strategies on the Moot case. After the end of the seminar, students should have acquired a good knowledge of, inter alia, the Convention on the International Sale of Good, the general structure of administered arbitration and the basic tools for research and advocacy on a practical problem.

course_outline:
Legal Education is presently facing challenges related to the internationalization of the legal profession. New, truly international, learning experiences are flourishing, and in particular extremely useful and challenging international commercial arbitration moots. One of the most prestigious is the Vis (East) Moot. As the organizers of this competition state, the Vis Moot was created as a clinical tool for training law students in crucial aspects of the procedure: research, drafting and advocacy. The goals of the Moot are the promotion and study of international commercial arbitration and the training of tomorrow's legal leaders in methods of alternate dispute resolution.

This seminar focuses on both theoretical and practical issues related to the Moot. This year (2014) case will be studied in detail. Starting from that, students will have to prepare the case (doing research and collecting materials), develop a defensive strategy and learn the basic skills of oral advocacy in arbitration. As the Moot case is based on the Convention on the International Sale of Goods (CISG) the seminar will be an occasion for an in-depth study of this extremely useful international convention.

Ordinary students will work together with the Nagoya University Team for the Vis (East) Moot 2015, in order to get a first-hand experience of how preparing for a moot is.

textbooks:

course_outline:
International protection of human rights has largely developed under the auspices of the United Nations. Especially, international law in the field of human rights has much contributed to such developments.

This course is designed to provide students general knowledge of international human rights law in the first half part, and from such perspectives, to discuss rather specific problems/situations around the world in the second half part.

(The "international human rights law" mentioned above include, for example, the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights, the Convention of the Rights of Child, etc.)

The discussion of the course will evolve around the following questions:

  1. What principles should base the foundations of the international human rights law?

  2. Under what conditions can an international law system contribute to the realization of universal protection of human rights?

  3. What are challeges of current international human rights law and institutions?

Students are required to study assigned reading materials prior to each class and to be prepared for discussions.

course_outline:
本講義は、日本についてほとんど知らないという状況のまま入学している本コース留学生に、日本社会、日本法についての概括的な情報を提供するために、弁護士の方と名大の教員が協力して、裁判所、検察庁、弁護士会、法務関連機関、企業等の訪問を軸に、日本の法制度の学習を行い、それらの総合学習を踏まえ、自国の制度と社会と比較し、自国の未来を展望するレポートを提出させるという、講義と実地見学を組み合わせた講義です。

講義では、資料の予習、実地見学前の概説、実地見学、見学に基づく質疑応答、自分の国の制度との比較を通じた自国の法と社会のより的確な理解を深めることを目標とています。日本社会と日本法を知るための実地見学を本講義ではかなり重視しています。講義の達成目標は、半年の講義で日本の社会と法制度の全体像について、一定の実感をもってもらうことです。　

It would appear that the overseas students entering the LL.M. in Comparative Law Program (English-taught program) arrive knowing very little about Japan. However, the curriculum of this course deals with advanced theories of law in each of its lecture series with a lack of explanations for those new to Japanese law and society.　Therefore, to give overseas students some general information regarding Japan, this course is run, in conjunction with the Aichi Prefectural Bar Association (International Special Committee) and the teaching staff of Nagoya University.

Lectures are given in conjunction with onsite visits (around half the time for each. Several lectures are taken). The lectures consist of the prior study of relevant materials, explanations before visits, question and answer sessions based on the visits, and the comparison of the system in Japan with one's own country so as to further one's understanding of the law and society of one's country. It is important that the onsite visits become the core part of the lectures so as to enhance one's knowledge of Japanese society and law.

Emerged in this varied learning experience, students make comparisons with their own countries' system and society, and submit reports on the future perspective they have for their country. course_title: Introduction to Joint Research on Comparative Study of Law
course_objective:
A few words to begin with...:

"National systems still dominate the agenda of most legal scholars and the curricula of most students of law not simply for practical reasons but as much because this remains for most people the definition of what legal education and legal scholarship are about. But law students and legal scholars deserve something better, and it remains a major task for comparative lawyers to show them the ways to get it. But it may need some imagination."

"Imagination is not a word that is commonly used in relation to legal studies. Traditionally, more emphasis is placed on knowledge and understanding. (...) Once one accepts that the development of the imagination should be an important feature of legal education and legal scholarship alongside the acquisition of knowledge and the increase of understanding, the means of stimulating it can, in principle, be as wide-ranging as possible. (...)"

Geoffrey WILSON, 'Comparative Legal Scholarship', in M. McConville, W. Hong Chui, Research Methods for Law, Edinburgh: Edinburgh University Press, 2012, p. 97-98-99.

This workshop is designed for students in law and in politics working in a collaborative international setting.

  • Through various readings, they can LEARN FROM the often messy but theoretically informed and constructive methodological choices made by comparative legal scholars in a wide range of projects ;

  • Through various exercises, they can LEARN HOW to engage themselves in comparative legal research.

This workshop revolves around two main features.

  • First, by focusing on the "Comparative Study of Law" broadly conceived rather than on "Comparative Law" in the narrow sense, it makes students more knowledgeable about various comparative methods applicable to a wide range of legal institutions at different regulatory levels and in different contexts. Students are able to explore and compare multiple legal norms, rules and principles that stem from diverse public and private rule-making entities at local, national and international levels.

  • Second, by prioritizing "Joint Research", this workshop creates a learning environment that is conducive to the learning of basic research skills following an original pattern. It gives students with divergent national, linguistic and academic backgrounds the opportunity both to step away from soloist and monodisciplinary types of comparativism, and to cease thinking in terms of a single national legal paradigm. In such an international and collaborative setting, students are stimulated to exchange a variety of perspectives. Rather than concentrating on simply executing a standard procedure of doing research, they are challenged - through teamwork and cooperative learning - to explore innovative formulas to study law comparatively, to construct their own understanding of the law from multiple sources, and to elaborate workable alternative solutions to real-world problems.

Small-scale, student-centred, based on complementary teaching methods and learning styles (lectures, discussions with reading assignments before classes, case studies, project- and problem-based assignment tasks), this workshop equips pluralistic legal-minded students with a "tool-box" on which they can draw in a creative manner to actually engage in comparative legal research and better navigate today's complex and rapidly transforming legal landscape. Through focusing on the process of learning, rather than the mere content to be learned, this "Introduction to Joint Research on Comparative Study of Law" should allow students to develop the capability of applying, not only possessing, knowledge that can be used in various contextualized settings. The basics acquired through such workshop relate to a wide range of transferable skills* to be developed further through the overall Leading Program.

  • Such as the ability to undertake a critical analysis of legal concepts and institutions across systems; an appreciation of legal pluralism and varying forms of normativity; the ability to identify and resolve theoretical and practical problems concerning the application of law in multi-jurisdictional situations; and the capacity to place law and regulation, irrespective of subject area, within a global context.

course_outline:
Why and how to engage in the comparative study of law? Recent years have witnessed an intense debate over new directions in legal comparativism and innovative efforts to renew the field have been made. Significantly, a methodologically sound approach to comparative legal study and research is now considered to be crucial in the production of a growing body of critical understanding of legal matters in the era of globalization. Moreover, clear guidelines are deemed necessary, especially at a time when young students engage more often than in the past in legal research conducted on a comparative basis.

Addressing the question of how to carry out comparative legal research, this workshop explores the main methodological traditions and their practical implications in comparing different legal institutions in a multifaceted, globalized world. It introduces students to both an overarching methodological framework (consisting of a series of steps that need to be taken to perform any comparative legal research project) and a wide range of various comparative "techniques" that have developed over time by trial and error. All together, its 7 sessions form a plea for a comprehensive approach to methodology regarding the comparative study of law.

The first part of this workshop will consist of a theoretical inquiry in established, as well as more innovative, comparative law methods. We will critically discuss these methods and study how to apply them to the most controversial issues in current legal debates (Sessions 1 and 2). Then, we will turn our attention to the impact of globalization on legal systems and will challenge the relevance of the comparative law method in addressing today's larger, complex web of overlapping, competing and conflicting legal sources (Sessions 3 to 5). Composed of two training sessions, the second part will focus on legal research basic skills development. Through collaborative and open research assignments, students will learn both how to rely on a comprehensive framework of comparative legal research and to confront a variety of possible methodological choices. Devoted respectively to problem-based and project-based assignment tasks, Session 6 and Session 7 will allow students to engage with comparative study of law in such a way that research processes are internalised rather than being conveyed by a top-down approach.

course_outline:
It has been six years since Uzbek government forces killed hundreds of

unarmed protesters in the eastern city of Andijan on May 13, 2005, following prison attacks by armed men.

Divergent views persist today with regard to this Andijan tragedy in the

context of human rights and democracy.

The position taken by the Uzbek government, supported by Russia, China and countries in Central Asia, places the blame on the terrorists. It claims that the armed group belonged to the terrorists group known as Akramia - a faction of the illegal Hizb-ut-Tahri (an Islam fundamentalist Party), which sought to establish an Islamic State refusing to accept human rights and democracy. They attacked the prison and used citizens as human shield while attempting to withdraw. That was how the gun battle started and they should be held responsible for the deaths. Uzbekistan has no choice but to respond to "violence" by the Islamic fundamentalists, who reject human rights and democracy, with equal "violence". The argument states that, for a premature secular state that had gained independence for merely 20 years, any response to "violence" by means of respects for human rights and democracy would lead to the demise of the State and therefore the ends of human rights and democracy. (Cry like a wolf when living with the wolf).

Against this first view, countries in the West and international human

rights NGOs come up with their critical arguments that human rights have

been violated in Uzbekistan under the pretext of fighting terrorism led by

the Islamic fundamentalists. Even a young independent State of 20 years old

has the duty to respect human rights and democracy. Notwithstanding the

future goal of human rights and democracy, "violence" in response to

"violence" will create a vicious circle of violence and hatred. The future goal will never be achievable.

Six years after the Andijan tragedy, this criticism against Uzbekistan has not changed. For example, the Human Rights Watch includes the following

wordings in its 2012 World Report: Uzbekistan's human rights record remains appalling, with no meaningful improvements in 2011. Torture remains endemic in the criminal justice system. Authorities continue to target civil society activists, opposition members, and journalists, and to persecute religious believers who worship outside strict state controls.

What should be the appropriate way for Uzbekistan, a State in the process

of building and the front line of the war against terror, to develop its own goals of human rights and democracy? How should legal assistance proceed to promote the development of human rights and democracy in this country? This paper reviews some lessons learned from the JICA's experience of legal assistance (assistance in drafting the law on administrative procedure) in Uzbekistan and raises some issues which may be useful for the development of comparative studies in administrative law.

course_objective:
We will first take a general look at traditional Chinese family law and how it spread to surrounding areas including the Korean peninsula and Japan. We will compare the differences between indigenous Japanese and Korean family law. Though both received the influence of traditional Chinese family law their laws developed slightly differently due to variances in the cultures of each. While both countries have modified their own legal systems using first Chinese and later "modern" systems from abroad this process did not constitute a total replacement of the older systems with newer, more advanced ones.

Secondly we will discuss issues related to South Asian family law, comparing India, Pakistan, Bangladesh and other surrounding countries. Religions such as Hinduism and Islam have had a great influence on the Indian subcontinent and religious and customary laws are applied to family issues. The general legal system that has been transplanted from European countries co-exists in these countries with personal laws and the choice of applicable law is often permitted in family matters. The big issues to be discussed in these lectures will include whether the European influenced systems of general law should over-ride customary laws, whether family laws should be uniformed, and whether and how "international standards" on the protection of human rights should be introduced when they seem to conflict with personal laws.
course_outline: The purpose of this course is to allow students to develop the skills needed to understand foreign legal systems and search for better ways of building appropriate legal systems for different communities using comparative techniques.  This series of lectures focuses mainly on East and South Asia.  Because "Asia" is a vast region with a multitude of cultural backgrounds we do not have a clear definition of the term "Asian law". Not many universities in the world provide courses on "Asian law" at either the undergraduate or graduate level. The term is often used to refer simply to Chinese law, even in Asia, or Indian law as it is in the United Kingdom.  In this course we use East Asia in order to understand contemporary Japanese law more clearly and South Asia in order to gain a better understanding of the reality surrounding the application of religious laws.  During the course of these lectures we will learn how to locate proper sources, a skill that is essential in finding the applicable law and solving conflict of law problems.  An example of this would be finding the conditions necessary for a valid marriage in the case of a mixed marriage.

Rule of law remains a fundamental element of any functioning democracy. The clear expression of the will of the parliament that is binding upon all is a hallmark of a functioning society.

The drafting process is a key aspect in the machinery of government. The parliamentary system provides the means of accountability of the government. Yet, it also serves an important role in transforming the policy developed by the political actors into legislation for the polity. Using the Australian federal system as the example students will consider the constitutional and parliamentary arrangements though which legislation is enacted. course_outline:
Focusing on the World Bank and its activities, this course studies the relationship between law, justice and development. Efforts to use law as a tool to promote development through a justice lens will be at the core of our discussions. In the last two decades especially, international organizations, states, aid agencies, academics, and local and international non-governmental organizations have become commendably active and committed to mainstreaming law and justice into the development agenda.

The conceptions of development that underlie national and international actions are diverse, having economic, social, and political dimensions. We will take an expansive view of law and justice, recognizing that in many contexts, they also border on political, cultural and socio-economic issues. Putting these into perspective, we will analyze how development practitioners have tried to devise innovative and creative ways to keep up with the changing and expanding needs of today's world and the different initiatives that back these efforts.

As an international financial institution with a development mandate, the World Bank has been involved in a great deal of these efforts―as an institution and, sometimes, in partnership with other institutions. We will take a critical look at some of the World Bank's development initiatives, especially in the area of justice reform. We will also look at case studies of a few projects, focusing on the policies and procedures of the Bank, the project cycle, and development approaches. In doing these, we will examine successes and failures, challenges faced and lessons learned, as well as current trends and prospects for the future for both the Bank and the development field in general. The course will wind up with a practical exercise involving a justice reform project in a fragile state. Students will have the opportunity to consider the dynamics of justice reform and the interests and considerations underlying investment decisions and development efforts.
